answers.answerLabel: A reusable building block for the user interface
A style in Angular
A service for handling HTTP requests
A routing configuration
NgModule is used to declare and configure modules in Angular applications.
NgModule is a component in Angular.
NgModule is used for data binding in Angular.
NgModule is a directive in Angular.
You can create a new Angular application using the Angular CLI by running 'ng new app-name'.
You can create a new Angular application by writing HTML and CSS files.
You can create a new Angular application using pure JavaScript.
You can create a new Angular application using Python.
Data binding in Angular is a mechanism for synchronizing data between the component and the view.
Data binding in Angular is used for creating components.
Data binding in Angular is a routing feature.
Data binding in Angular is only available for services.
{{}} (interpolation) is used for displaying dynamic data in the template.
[property] (property binding) is used for displaying dynamic data in the template.
{{}} (interpolation) is used for creating CSS styles.
[property] (property binding) is used for creating services.
Event binding in Angular is used to capture and respond to user interactions like clicks and keystrokes.
Event binding in Angular is used for defining component styles.
Event binding in Angular is used for defining routes.
Event binding in Angular is used for dependency injection.
Angular CLI (Command Line Interface) is a command-line tool for creating, building, and deploying Angular applications.
Angular CLI is a component in Angular applications.
Angular CLI is a directive in Angular applications.
Angular CLI is a service for handling HTTP requests.
A directive in Angular is a marker on a DOM element that tells Angular to do something with that element.
A directive in Angular is a component.
A directive in Angular is a service.
A directive in Angular is a module.
The Angular router is a library for navigating between views and components.
The Angular router is used for handling HTTP requests.
The Angular router is used for data binding in Angular.
The Angular router is used for event binding in Angular.
Dependency injection in Angular is a design pattern used to provide instances of classes with their dependencies.
Dependency injection in Angular is a way to inject styles into components.
Dependency injection in Angular is a way to create routes in an application.
Dependency injection in Angular is used for data binding.
Communication between parent and child components in Angular can be achieved through input properties and output events.
Communication between parent and child components in Angular is not possible.
Communication between parent and child components in Angular can only be done using services.
Communication between parent and child components in Angular can only be done using event binding.
A service in Angular is a class that provides specific functionality and can be injected into components and other services.
A service in Angular is a type of component.
A service in Angular is a type of directive.
A service in Angular is a type of module.
The ngFor directive in Angular is used for iterating over a list of items and rendering them in the template.
The ngFor directive in Angular is used for defining routes.
The ngFor directive in Angular is used for handling HTTP requests.
The ngFor directive in Angular is used for event binding.
Modules in Angular are used to organize the application into cohesive blocks of functionality.
Modules in Angular are used for data binding.
Modules in Angular are used for routing configuration.
Modules in Angular are used for handling HTTP requests.
Angular CLI's 'ng serve' command is used to compile and serve an Angular application locally for development purposes.
Angular CLI's 'ng serve' command is used to deploy an Angular application to a production server.
Angular CLI's 'ng serve' command is used for data binding.
Angular CLI's 'ng serve' command is used for event binding.
Angular's two-way data binding combines property binding and event binding to automatically keep the view and the component data in sync.
Angular's two-way data binding is used for routing configuration.
Angular's two-way data binding is used for dependency injection.
Angular's two-way data binding is used for handling HTTP requests.
Angular's trackBy function is used to improve the performance of ngFor by identifying unique items in the iteration.
Angular's trackBy function is used for defining routes.
Angular's trackBy function is used for event binding.
Angular's trackBy function is used for dependency injection.
HTTP requests in Angular can be handled using the HttpClient module to send requests and receive responses from a server.
HTTP requests in Angular can be handled using the ngFor directive.
HTTP requests in Angular can be handled using dependency injection.
HTTP requests in Angular can be handled using the trackBy function.
Angular pipes are used for transforming and formatting data in templates.
Angular pipes are used for defining routes.
Angular pipes are used for event binding.
Angular pipes are used for dependency injection.
Lazy loading in Angular is a technique for loading modules only when they are needed, improving application performance.
Lazy loading in Angular is a technique for handling HTTP requests.
Lazy loading in Angular is a technique for event binding.
Lazy loading in Angular is a technique for defining routes.
It subscribes to an Observable/Promise and returns the latest value, handling unsubscribe automatically.
It converts Observables into Promises globally.
It triggers change detection manually on the component.
It creates a new subscription service instance.
Use [ngClass] or [class.className] bindings with a boolean condition.
Use the style tag with an if statement in HTML.
Only possible using a custom directive.
It cannot be done in Angular templates.
A variable declared with # in the template to reference an element or directive instance.
A special variable created in the component class using @Input.
A service used to share data between components.
A CSS selector used by Angular to style elements.
Two-way data binding for form fields in template-driven forms (requires FormsModule and a name attribute).
It is only used to style input elements.
It disables the form control validation.
It is used to generate reactive form controls automatically.
Using @Output with EventEmitter in the child and handling the event in the parent.
Only by calling a parent public method directly from the template.
By editing the parent's private fields from the child.
It is not possible to send data to a parent component.
@Input
@Output
@Injectable
@Directive
To get a reference to a template element or child component instance inside the component class.
To declare inputs for a component.
To intercept HTTP calls globally.
To configure router navigation extras.
Projecting content from a parent into a child using the <ng-content> tag.
Adding styles to a child from a parent using ::ng-deep.
Loading components dynamically with ViewContainerRef.
Sharing state between routes with a resolver.
By adding a children array to a route configuration.
By creating a second RouterModule.forRoot() call.
By placing multiple router-outlet elements in index.html only.
By using a custom directive on router-outlet.
Applies a CSS class when the associated link's route becomes active.
Disables navigation for the link when clicked.
Performs a redirect automatically to the first child route.
Loads the component lazily when hovered.
To decide if a route can be activated (navigation allowed).
To pre-load assets before application bootstrap.
To transform HTTP responses globally.
To generate routes using the CLI.
Define routes with :param and read via ActivatedRoute (params/snapshot).
Only query strings are supported for passing data to routes.
Use a global service to share data instead of params.
Pass parameters by editing window.location.hash manually.
Registers the service in the root injector (single app-wide instance, tree-shakable).
Prevents the service from being injected in lazy modules.
Creates a new instance for each component injection site.
Disables Angular's dependency injection for the service.
To provide a token for DI when a type is not available (e.g., interfaces, config values).
To declare a new component selector at runtime.
To intercept and modify route parameters.
To style components using tokens in CSS.
'root' is tree-shakable app-wide singleton; module providers can create distinct instances per (lazy) module.
Both options always create a new instance per component.
Providing in a module makes the service unavailable in child modules.
Providing in 'root' disables lazy loading for routes.
ng generate service my-service (alias: ng g s my-service)
ng create service my-service
ng make service my-service
ng generate module my-service
A module file and a routing module preconfigured for feature routes (using forChild).
Only a routing module with forRoot configuration.
A service and a component.
A lazy-loaded route automatically registered in app-routing.
ng build --configuration production (alias: -c production)
ng serve --prod
ng start --production
ng compile --prod
To group related functionality (components, routes, services) into a cohesive area of the app.
To hold only global styles for the application.
To replace the root AppModule.
To manage environment variables.
To declare and export commonly used components/pipes/directives for reuse across modules.
To configure the global HTTP interceptors.
To bootstrap the Angular application.
To declare providers for every feature service.
forRoot configures providers and should be called once in root; forChild is for feature modules.
Both are deprecated and should not be used anywhere.
forChild must be used in AppModule only.
forRoot should be called in every lazy module.
Intercepts HTTP requests/responses to read/modify or add headers, handle errors, etc.
Generates Angular services automatically from responses.
Provides built-in authentication without configuration.
Converts Observables into Promises for all requests.
this.http.get<T>(url) and subscribe to the Observable.
this.http.request('FETCH', url)
this.http.fetch(url).toPromise()
window.fetch(url).subscribe()
Observables are lazy, can emit multiple values and be canceled; Promises are eager and emit a single value.
Observables always resolve faster than Promises in Angular.
Promises are lazy and emit multiple values; Observables are eager and single-shot.
They are identical in behavior and performance.
Use RxJS catchError with HttpErrorResponse handling (and possibly retry), or subscribe error callback.
Wrap the request in try/catch without using Observables.
Errors are auto-handled by Angular; no code is needed.
Only use global error handlers in index.html.
BehaviorSubject stores the latest value and emits it immediately to new subscribers; Subject does not store a current value.
Subject stores the latest value; BehaviorSubject does not.
Both are identical in behavior.
BehaviorSubject cannot be subscribed to after it's created.
A directive that changes DOM structure, applied with * syntax (e.g., *ngIf, *ngFor).
A directive used only for styling without changing DOM.
A special component that cannot have inputs.
A router-only directive to navigate between pages.
It limits change detection to input reference changes, events, and async updates; improves performance.
It disables change detection entirely for the component.
It forces change detection to run twice as often.
It enables server-side rendering for the component.
Use loadChildren with a dynamic import: loadChildren: () => import('./feature/feature.module').then(m => m.FeatureModule)
Add multiple RouterModule.forRoot() calls in every module.
Use routerLink with a lazy attribute on the template.
Only possible using third-party libraries.
Pass HttpHeaders in the options object: this.http.get(url, { headers: new HttpHeaders({ ... }) }).
Set window.headers before calling HttpClient methods.
Headers cannot be sent with HttpClient.
Add headers by editing angular.json build options only.
